item.title: On asyncio run
item.description: Python formally introduced concurrency using asncio in 3.7+. A simple program that can demonstrate the hello world of async stuff goes like this- import asyncio async def main(): print('hello') await asyncio.sleep(1) print('world') asyncio.run(main()) In this case asyncio.run is the blocking call. It takes coroutine as a param, that is created by main() due to the async qualifer. Does it also create an event loop inside? From the doc, yes it does-
